chapter.title: Installation and Documentation Packages
chapter.para:
Talend ESB SE is delivered as two separate packages, one containing the software and the other containing the documentation and examples. It is recommended that both packages be extracted to a common directory location.
Binary distribution:
talend-esb-4.0.[tar.gz|zip]
Documentation and Examples:
talend-esb-4.0-doc.[tar.gz|zip]

para.para: The following outlines the installation directory structure for both packages.

row.entry: Libraries required for the Talend ESB Service Locator and Monitoring features
Command line tools/shell scripts (e.g. code generation)
Pre-configured OSGi container based on Eclipse Equinox and Apache Karaf
API documentation for Apache CXF in Javadoc format
Various configuration files for Apache CXF
Libraries required for using Talend ESB (see WHICH_JARS for more details)
License documents for the third party components included in Talend ESB
Libraries that comprise Apache CXF (used to create lightweight distributions of CXF if not all functionality is required)
The standard example source code that comes with Apache CXF and Apache Camel
Apache ZooKeeper which is required for the Talend ESB Service Locator feature
Manuals and User Guides for Talend ESB in PDF format
Extended, documented examples for Talend ESB

chapter.title: System Requirements
chapter.section: Hardware Requirements Talend ESB does not have any specific hardware requirements, beyond the recommended hardware requirements for the supporting application server or Java runtime environment.

section.title: Software Requirements
section.para: Talend ESB is supported on the following operating systems:

itemizedlist.listitem: Windows XP (>= Service Pack 2), Windows Vista, Windows 7
Windows Server 2003 (>= Service Pack 2), Windows Server 2008 or higher

section.para: Talend ESB is supported on the following Appserver and Java runtime environments:

itemizedlist.listitem: OSGi Runtime (Eclipse Equinox 3.6 / Apache Karaf 2.2.0 - included in this delivery)

chapter.title: Highlighted Features, Changes and Fixes
chapter.para: Talend ESB SE includes both the Talend Service Factory 2.4.0 and Talend Integration Factory 2.7.1 distributions.
In additional, Talend ESB SE 4.0 includes the following features:

section.title: Service Locator
section.para: The Service Locator in the add-ons directory is a service that provides its consumers with a mechanism to discover service endpoints at run time. The Service Locator consists of two parts: An Endpoint repository and a CXF feature used to configure the use of the Service Locator from both the provider and consumer sides. Like any standard CXF feature, the ServiceLocator Feature is configured separately for the service provider and service consumer. The provider side Locator Feature extension registers and deregisters service endpoints in the endpoint repository when the provider becomes available or unavailable. The consumer side Locator Feature extension transparently retrieves service endpoint addresses from the endpoint repository when a service call to a provider is to be made.

For more information how to install and configure the Service Locator see the Service Locator Installation Manual (docs/SLInstallationManual.pdf) and the Service Locator Configuration Manual (docs/SLConfigurationManual.pdf).

section.title: Service Activity Monitoring (SAM)
section.para: The Service Activity Monitoring (SAM) in the add-ons directory allows to log / monitor service calls done with the Apache CXF Framework. Typical use cases are usage statistics, fault monitoring and correlation of message across multiple services. SAM consists of two parts: 1. Agent (sam-agent) and 2. Monitoring Server (sam-server). The Agent creates events out of the requests and replies on service consumer and provider side. The events are first collected locally and then sent to the monitoring server periodically to not disturb the normal message flow. The Monitoring Server receives events from the Agent, optionally filters/handlers events and stores them into a Database.
For more information about the Service Activity Monitoring feature see the Service Activity Monitoring User Guide (docs/SAMUserGuide.pdf).

section.title: Car Rental Demo
section.para: The Car Rental Demo is a simplified real-world example, using the domain of car rental companies to demonstrate the use of Talend ESB for developing and deploying services. It comes with a detailed Getting Started Guide that step by step describes how to compile the demo, deploy it into the Talend ESB Runtime OSGi container and then activate it. The demo also shows how to enable the Service Locator Component for the services deployed in the demo, and how Service Activity Monitoring can be enabled.
For more information about the Car Rental Demo see the Getting Started Guide (docs/GettingStartedGuide.pdf).

section.title: Talend Service Factory 2.4.0
section.para: Talend ESB contains the Talend Service Factory 2.4.0 with a lot of new features.

itemizedlist.listitem: Transformation feature provides for a fast and effective way to transform inbound and/or outbound XML messages.

Faster startup and reduced spring configuration. The Spring support has been redone to be based on the ExtensionManagerBus. This results in much faster startup. It also means that all of the imports of META-INF/cxf/cxf-extension-*.xml are no longer needed.

WSS4J has been updated from 1.5.x to 1.6. Some notable new features for CXF users include:
SAML2 support: WSS4J 1.6 includes full support for creating, manipulating and parsing SAML2 assertions, via the Opensaml2 library.
Performance work: A general code-rewrite has been done with a focus on improving performance.
Support for Crypto trust-stores: WSS4J 1.6 separates the concept of keystore and truststores.

Initial Apache Aries Blueprint support. This is a work in progress, but many of the Spring namespace handlers that are used with Spring to start/create/configure clients and services now have Blueprint versions as well. See http://cxf.apache.org/schemas/blueprint/ for some of the schemas that have been ported to Blueprint.

section.para: For more information about the Talend Service Factory see the Talend Service Factory User Guide (docs/TSFUsersGuide.pdf).
For more details please see: Apache CXF 2.4 migration guide.

section.title: Talend Integration Factory 2.7.1
section.para: Talend ESB contains the Talend Integration Factory 2.7.1 with a lot of new features.

itemizedlist.listitem: Added 4 new components: Context, Hazelcast Component, DNS and MyBatis
Switched to using slf4j as the logger instead of commons logging
Added support for MDC logging with Camel
Improvements for a few components like JMS, HTTP, File, Quartz
Improvements of the test kit and Mock component
fixes and improvements related to using Camel in OSGi

section.para: For more information about the Talend Integration Factory see the Talend Integration Factory User Guide (docs/TIFUsersGuide.pdf).
For more details please see the: Apache Camel 2.7.0 release notes and the Apache Camel 2.7.1 release notes.

chapter.title: Known Limitations

para.emphasis: SAM Server is required to be deployed on Apache Tomcat container.

chapter.para: In this release of the Talend ESB the Service Activity Management (SAM) Server is required to be deployed on Tomcat 6. In future versions of Talend ESB we will also support the deployment within the Talend ESB OSGi container.

chapter.title: Reporting Defects and Issues
chapter.para: For community technical support use the Talend User's Forum at Talend Forum - Talend ESB. You can also look at the Open and Fixed issues provided in the Bug tracker Talend Bug Tracker - Project: Talend ESB

If you have a valid customer support contract for Talend ESB (SE/EE) with Talend you can access the Talend Online Helpdesk or you can contact customer support by phone and e-mail as stated in your contracts.

Please provide the following information:
Product and Version which you used (for example, Talend ESB 4.0 SE)
Version of Java Platform JDK / JRE in use.
Log files
Also, in order to ensure that the technical support team has sufficient information to help you, describe at least the following in detail:
your actions up to the point when the problem occurred
the results you expected
the ensuing results that differ from your expected results.
